trans-unit.source: Step 4: Train and evaluate the predictive analytic models | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: Step 4: Train and evaluate the predictive analytic models | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: Step 4 of the Develop a predictive solution walkthrough: Train, score, and evaluate multiple models in Azure Machine Learning Studio.
trans-unit.target: Step 4 of the Develop a predictive solution walkthrough: Train, score, and evaluate multiple models in Azure Machine Learning Studio.

trans-unit.source: Walkthrough Step 4: Train and evaluate the predictive analytic models
trans-unit.target: Walkthrough Step 4: Train and evaluate the predictive analytic models

trans-unit.source: This is the fourth step of the walkthrough, [Developing a Predictive Solution with Azure ML](machine-learning-walkthrough-develop-predictive-solution.md)
trans-unit.target: This is the fourth step of the walkthrough, [Developing a Predictive Solution with Azure ML](machine-learning-walkthrough-develop-predictive-solution.md)

trans-unit.source: Create a Machine Learning workspace
trans-unit.target: Create a Machine Learning workspace

trans-unit.source: Upload existing data
trans-unit.target: Upload existing data

trans-unit.source: Create a new experiment
trans-unit.target: Create a new experiment

trans-unit.source: Train and evaluate the models
trans-unit.target: Train and evaluate the models

trans-unit.source: Publish the web service
trans-unit.target: Publish the web service

trans-unit.source: Access the web service
trans-unit.target: Access the web service

trans-unit.source: In this experiment we want to try different algorithms for our predictive model.
trans-unit.target: In this experiment we want to try different algorithms for our predictive model.

trans-unit.source: We'll create two different types of models and then compare their scoring results to decide which algorithm we want to use in our final experiment.
trans-unit.target: We'll create two different types of models and then compare their scoring results to decide which algorithm we want to use in our final experiment.

trans-unit.source: There are a number of models we could choose from.
trans-unit.target: There are a number of models we could choose from.

trans-unit.source: To see the models available, expand the **Machine Learning** node in the module palette, and then expand **Initialize Model** and the nodes beneath it.
trans-unit.target: To see the models available, expand the **Machine Learning** node in the module palette, and then expand **Initialize Model** and the nodes beneath it.

trans-unit.source: For the purposes of this experiment, we'll select the Support Vector Machine (SVM) and the Two-Class Boosted Decision Trees modules.
trans-unit.target: For the purposes of this experiment, we'll select the Support Vector Machine (SVM) and the Two-Class Boosted Decision Trees modules.

trans-unit.source: We'll use the appropriate modules to initialize the learning algorithms and use [Train Model][train-model] modules to train the models.
trans-unit.target: We'll use the appropriate modules to initialize the learning algorithms and use [Train Model][train-model] modules to train the models.

trans-unit.source: Train the models
trans-unit.target: Train the models

trans-unit.source: First, let's set up the boosted decision tree model:
trans-unit.target: First, let's set up the boosted decision tree model:

trans-unit.source: Find the [Two-Class Boosted Decision Tree][two-class-boosted-decision-tree] module in the module palette and drag it onto the canvas.
trans-unit.target: Find the [Two-Class Boosted Decision Tree][two-class-boosted-decision-tree] module in the module palette and drag it onto the canvas.

trans-unit.source: Find the [Train Model][train-model] module, drag it onto the canvas, and then connect the output of the boosted decision tree module to the left input port ("Untrained model") of the [Train Model][train-model] module.
trans-unit.target: Find the [Train Model][train-model] module, drag it onto the canvas, and then connect the output of the boosted decision tree module to the left input port ("Untrained model") of the [Train Model][train-model] module.

trans-unit.source: Connect the left output ("Result Dataset") of the left [Execute R Script][execute-r-script] module to the right input port ("Dataset") of the [Train Model][train-model] module.
trans-unit.target: Connect the left output ("Result Dataset") of the left [Execute R Script][execute-r-script] module to the right input port ("Dataset") of the [Train Model][train-model] module.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.TIP] We don't need two of the inputs and one of the outputs of the [Execute R Script][execute-r-script] module for this experiment, so we'll just leave them unattached.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.TIP] We don't need two of the inputs and one of the outputs of the [Execute R Script][execute-r-script] module for this experiment, so we'll just leave them unattached.

trans-unit.source: This is not uncommon for some modules.
trans-unit.target: This is not uncommon for some modules.

trans-unit.source: Select the [Train Model][train-model] module.
trans-unit.target: Select the [Train Model][train-model] module.

trans-unit.source: In the **Properties** pane, click **Launch column selector**, select **Include** in the first dropdown, select **column indices** in the second dropdown, and enter "21" in the text field (you can also select **column names** and enter "Credit Risk").
trans-unit.target: In the **Properties** pane, click **Launch column selector**, select **Include** in the first dropdown, select **column indices** in the second dropdown, and enter "21" in the text field (you can also select **column names** and enter "Credit Risk").

trans-unit.source: This identifies column 21, the credit risk value, as the column for the model to predict.
trans-unit.target: This identifies column 21, the credit risk value, as the column for the model to predict.

trans-unit.source: This portion of the experiment now looks something like this:
trans-unit.target: This portion of the experiment now looks something like this:

trans-unit.source: Training a model
trans-unit.target: Training a model

trans-unit.source: Next, we'll set up the SVM model.
trans-unit.target: Next, we'll set up the SVM model.

trans-unit.source: Boosted decision trees work well with features of any type.
trans-unit.target: Boosted decision trees work well with features of any type.

trans-unit.source: However, since the SVM module generates a linear classifier, the model that it generates has the best test error when all numeric features have the same scale.
trans-unit.target: However, since the SVM module generates a linear classifier, the model that it generates has the best test error when all numeric features have the same scale.

trans-unit.source: To convert all numeric features to the same scale, we use the [Normalize Data][normalize-data] module with a Tanh transformation, which transforms features into the [0,1] range.
trans-unit.target: To convert all numeric features to the same scale, we use the [Normalize Data][normalize-data] module with a Tanh transformation, which transforms features into the [0,1] range.

trans-unit.source: Note that string features are converted by the SVM module to categorical features and then to binary 0/1 features, so we don't need to manually transform string features.
trans-unit.target: Note that string features are converted by the SVM module to categorical features and then to binary 0/1 features, so we don't need to manually transform string features.

trans-unit.source: Also, we don't want to transform the Credit Risk column (column 21) - it's numeric, but it's the value we're training the model to predict, so we need to leave it alone.
trans-unit.target: Also, we don't want to transform the Credit Risk column (column 21) - it's numeric, but it's the value we're training the model to predict, so we need to leave it alone.

trans-unit.source: Find the [Two-Class Support Vector Machine][two-class-support-vector-machine] module in the module palette and drag it onto the canvas.
trans-unit.target: Find the [Two-Class Support Vector Machine][two-class-support-vector-machine] module in the module palette and drag it onto the canvas.

trans-unit.source: Right-click the [Train Model][train-model] module, select **Copy**, and then right-click the canvas and select **Paste**.
trans-unit.target: Right-click the [Train Model][train-model] module, select **Copy**, and then right-click the canvas and select **Paste**.

trans-unit.source: Note that the copy of the [Train Model][train-model] module has the same column selection as the original.
trans-unit.target: Note that the copy of the [Train Model][train-model] module has the same column selection as the original.

trans-unit.source: Connect the output of the SVM module to the left input port ("Untrained model") of the [Train Model][train-model] module.
trans-unit.target: Connect the output of the SVM module to the left input port ("Untrained model") of the [Train Model][train-model] module.

trans-unit.source: Find the [Normalize Data][normalize-data] module and drag it onto the canvas.
trans-unit.target: Find the [Normalize Data][normalize-data] module and drag it onto the canvas.

trans-unit.source: Connect the input of this transform module to the output of the left [Execute R Script][execute-r-script] module.
trans-unit.target: Connect the input of this transform module to the output of the left [Execute R Script][execute-r-script] module.

trans-unit.source: Connect the left output port ("Transformed Dataset") of the transform module to the right input port ("Dataset") of the [Train Model][train-model] module.
trans-unit.target: Connect the left output port ("Transformed Dataset") of the transform module to the right input port ("Dataset") of the [Train Model][train-model] module.

trans-unit.source: In the **Properties** pane for the transform module, select **Tanh** for the **Transformation method** parameter.
trans-unit.target: In the **Properties** pane for the transform module, select **Tanh** for the **Transformation method** parameter.

trans-unit.source: Click **Launch column selector**, select "No columns" for **Begin With**, select **Include** in the first dropdown, select **column type** in the second dropdown, and select **Numeric** in the third dropdown.
trans-unit.target: Click **Launch column selector**, select "No columns" for **Begin With**, select **Include** in the first dropdown, select **column type** in the second dropdown, and select **Numeric** in the third dropdown.

trans-unit.source: This specifies that all the numeric columns (and only numeric) will be transformed.
trans-unit.target: This specifies that all the numeric columns (and only numeric) will be transformed.

trans-unit.source: Click the plus sign (+), which creates a new row of dropdowns.
trans-unit.target: Click the plus sign (+), which creates a new row of dropdowns.

trans-unit.source: Select **Exclude** in the first dropdown, select **column indices** in the second dropdown, and enter "21" in the text field.
trans-unit.target: Select **Exclude** in the first dropdown, select **column indices** in the second dropdown, and enter "21" in the text field.

trans-unit.source: This specifies that column 21 (the Credit Risk column) will be ignored.
trans-unit.target: This specifies that column 21 (the Credit Risk column) will be ignored.

trans-unit.source: Click **OK**.
trans-unit.target: Click **OK**.

trans-unit.source: The [Normalize Data][normalize-data] module is now set to perform a Tanh transformation on all numeric columns except for the Credit Risk column.
trans-unit.target: The [Normalize Data][normalize-data] module is now set to perform a Tanh transformation on all numeric columns except for the Credit Risk column.

trans-unit.source: This portion of our experiment should now look something like this:
trans-unit.target: This portion of our experiment should now look something like this:

trans-unit.source: Training the second model
trans-unit.target: Training the second model

trans-unit.source: Score and evaluate the models
trans-unit.target: Score and evaluate the models

trans-unit.source: We'll use the scoring data that was separated out by the **Split** module to score our trained models.
trans-unit.target: We'll use the scoring data that was separated out by the **Split** module to score our trained models.

trans-unit.source: We can then compare the results of the two models to see which generated better results.
trans-unit.target: We can then compare the results of the two models to see which generated better results.

trans-unit.source: Find the [Score Model][score-model] module and drag it onto the canvas.
trans-unit.target: Find the [Score Model][score-model] module and drag it onto the canvas.

trans-unit.source: Connect the left input port of this module to the boosted decision tree model (that is, connect it to the output port of the [Train Model][train-model] module that's connected to the [Two-Class Boosted Decision Tree][two-class-boosted-decision-tree] module).
trans-unit.target: Connect the left input port of this module to the boosted decision tree model (that is, connect it to the output port of the [Train Model][train-model] module that's connected to the [Two-Class Boosted Decision Tree][two-class-boosted-decision-tree] module).

trans-unit.source: Connect the right input port of the [Score Model][score-model] module to the output of the right [Execute R Script][execute-r-script] module.
trans-unit.target: Connect the right input port of the [Score Model][score-model] module to the output of the right [Execute R Script][execute-r-script] module.

trans-unit.source: Copy and paste the [Score Model][score-model] module to create a second copy, or drag a new module onto the canvas.
trans-unit.target: Copy and paste the [Score Model][score-model] module to create a second copy, or drag a new module onto the canvas.

trans-unit.source: Connect the left input port of this module to the SVM model (that is, connect to the output port of the [Train Model][train-model] module that's connected to the [Two-Class Support Vector Machine][two-class-support-vector-machine] module).
trans-unit.target: Connect the left input port of this module to the SVM model (that is, connect to the output port of the [Train Model][train-model] module that's connected to the [Two-Class Support Vector Machine][two-class-support-vector-machine] module).

trans-unit.source: For the SVM model, we have to do the same transformation to the test data as we did to the training data.
trans-unit.target: For the SVM model, we have to do the same transformation to the test data as we did to the training data.

trans-unit.source: So copy and paste the [Normalize Data][normalize-data] module to create a second copy and connect it to the output of the right [Execute R Script][execute-r-script] module.
trans-unit.target: So copy and paste the [Normalize Data][normalize-data] module to create a second copy and connect it to the output of the right [Execute R Script][execute-r-script] module.

trans-unit.source: Connect the right input port of the [Score Model][score-model] module to the output of the [Normalize Data][normalize-data] module.
trans-unit.target: Connect the right input port of the [Score Model][score-model] module to the output of the [Normalize Data][normalize-data] module.

trans-unit.source: To evaluate the two scoring results we'll use the [Evaluate Model][evaluate-model] module.
trans-unit.target: To evaluate the two scoring results we'll use the [Evaluate Model][evaluate-model] module.

trans-unit.source: Find the [Evaluate Model][evaluate-model] module and drag it onto the canvas.
trans-unit.target: Find the [Evaluate Model][evaluate-model] module and drag it onto the canvas.

trans-unit.source: Connect the left input port to the output port of the [Score Model][score-model] module associated with the boosted decision tree model.
trans-unit.target: Connect the left input port to the output port of the [Score Model][score-model] module associated with the boosted decision tree model.

trans-unit.source: Connect the right input port to the other [Score Model][score-model] module.
trans-unit.target: Connect the right input port to the other [Score Model][score-model] module.

trans-unit.source: The experiment should now look something like this:
trans-unit.target: The experiment should now look something like this:

trans-unit.source: Evaluating both models
trans-unit.target: Evaluating both models

trans-unit.source: Click the **RUN** button below the canvas to run the experiment.
trans-unit.target: Click the **RUN** button below the canvas to run the experiment.

trans-unit.source: It may take a few minutes.
trans-unit.target: It may take a few minutes.

trans-unit.source: You'll see a spinning indicator on each module to indicate that it's running, and then a green check mark when the module is finished.
trans-unit.target: You'll see a spinning indicator on each module to indicate that it's running, and then a green check mark when the module is finished.

trans-unit.source: When all the modules have a check mark, the experiment has finished running.
trans-unit.target: When all the modules have a check mark, the experiment has finished running.

trans-unit.source: To check the results, click the output port of the [Evaluate Model][evaluate-model] module and select **View Results**.
trans-unit.target: To check the results, click the output port of the [Evaluate Model][evaluate-model] module and select **View Results**.

trans-unit.source: The [Evaluate Model][evaluate-model] module produces a pair of curves and metrics that allow you to compare the results of the two scored models.
trans-unit.target: The [Evaluate Model][evaluate-model] module produces a pair of curves and metrics that allow you to compare the results of the two scored models.

trans-unit.source: You can view the results as Receiver Operator Characteristic (ROC) curves, Precision/Recall curves, or Lift curves.
trans-unit.target: You can view the results as Receiver Operator Characteristic (ROC) curves, Precision/Recall curves, or Lift curves.

trans-unit.source: Additional data displayed includes a confusion matrix, cumulative values for the area under the curve (AUC), and other metrics.
trans-unit.target: Additional data displayed includes a confusion matrix, cumulative values for the area under the curve (AUC), and other metrics.

trans-unit.source: You can change the threshold value by moving the slider left or right and see how it affects the set of metrics.
trans-unit.target: You can change the threshold value by moving the slider left or right and see how it affects the set of metrics.

trans-unit.source: Click **Scored dataset** or **Scored dataset to compare** to highlight the associated curve and to display the associated metrics below.
trans-unit.target: Click **Scored dataset** or **Scored dataset to compare** to highlight the associated curve and to display the associated metrics below.

trans-unit.source: In the legend for the curves, "Scored dataset" corresponds to the left input port of the [Evaluate Model][evaluate-model] module - in our case, this is the boosted decision tree model.
trans-unit.target: In the legend for the curves, "Scored dataset" corresponds to the left input port of the [Evaluate Model][evaluate-model] module - in our case, this is the boosted decision tree model.

trans-unit.source: "Scored dataset to compare" corresponds to the right input port - the SVM model in our case.
trans-unit.target: "Scored dataset to compare" corresponds to the right input port - the SVM model in our case.

trans-unit.source: When you click one of these labels you will highlight the curve for that model and display the corresponding metrics below.
trans-unit.target: When you click one of these labels you will highlight the curve for that model and display the corresponding metrics below.

trans-unit.source: ROC curves for models
trans-unit.target: ROC curves for models

trans-unit.source: By examining these values you can decide which model is closest to giving you the results you're looking for.
trans-unit.target: By examining these values you can decide which model is closest to giving you the results you're looking for.

trans-unit.source: You can go back and iterate on your experiment by changing values in the different models.
trans-unit.target: You can go back and iterate on your experiment by changing values in the different models.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.TIP] Each time you run the experiment a record of that iteration is kept in the Run History.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.TIP] Each time you run the experiment a record of that iteration is kept in the Run History.

trans-unit.source: You can view these iterations, and return to any of them, by clicking **VIEW RUN HISTORY** below the canvas.
trans-unit.target: You can view these iterations, and return to any of them, by clicking **VIEW RUN HISTORY** below the canvas.

trans-unit.source: You can also click **Prior Run** in the **Properties** pane to return to the iteration immediately preceding the one you have open.
trans-unit.target: You can also click **Prior Run** in the **Properties** pane to return to the iteration immediately preceding the one you have open.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see [Manage experiment iterations in Azure Machine Learning Studio](machine-learning-manage-experiment-iterations.md).
trans-unit.target: For more information, see [Manage experiment iterations in Azure Machine Learning Studio](machine-learning-manage-experiment-iterations.md).

trans-unit.source: You can also make a copy of any iteration of your experiment by clicking **SAVE AS** below the canvas.
trans-unit.target: You can also make a copy of any iteration of your experiment by clicking **SAVE AS** below the canvas.

trans-unit.source: This makes a duplicate of the experiment, creating a new Run History to track your iterations of this version.
trans-unit.target: This makes a duplicate of the experiment, creating a new Run History to track your iterations of this version.

trans-unit.source: The new copy is displayed in the **EXPERIMENTS** list alongside the original.
trans-unit.target: The new copy is displayed in the **EXPERIMENTS** list alongside the original.

trans-unit.source: This can be helpful if you want to start a new branch of experiment iterations.
trans-unit.target: This can be helpful if you want to start a new branch of experiment iterations.

trans-unit.source: As an additional help to track the changes you make to module parameters, you can add comments to any module on the experiment canvas.
trans-unit.target: As an additional help to track the changes you make to module parameters, you can add comments to any module on the experiment canvas.

trans-unit.source: Just double-click the module or right-click and select **Edit Comment**.
trans-unit.target: Just double-click the module or right-click and select **Edit Comment**.

trans-unit.source: These comments are saved with the experiment iterations and can help you annotate your work.
trans-unit.target: These comments are saved with the experiment iterations and can help you annotate your work.

trans-unit.source: Next: [Publish the web service](machine-learning-walkthrough-5-publish-web-service.md)
trans-unit.target: Next: [Publish the web service](machine-learning-walkthrough-5-publish-web-service.md)

trans-unit.source: test
trans-unit.target: test
